prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for taking my 3yo out to do something fun whilst my partner is at work?
I will try and keep this short . 

Almost every weekend when I say lets take our kid out to the play centre or a farm ect I get one of maybe 3  excuses every time without fail . Either "I dont want to go out / I just wanna sit and play on the computer. " " ive been at work im tired I don't wanna go out / drive " or " I don't wanna spend the money on x, y ,z" ( we have money so its not like thats a real problem )   

Today a friend asked me if i wanted to go with her with the kids to the farm near us tomorrow and I said yes . I figured since we hadn't taken little one anywhere fun for a few weeks it would be nice . 

So I mentioned it to my partner and he goes off on one about how its not fair as he is at work and he would like to go blah blah . I said so I cant take her anywhere when you're at work ? Pointed out that I asked to go not a week or two earlier and was told no its too expencive and  I dont want to go out I'm tired. ( its £7 each ). 

So now he wants me to cancle with my friend so he can go another day . I said we can go whenever you want . But apparently thats not an option either . 

Its a childrens petting zoo ffs its not like im going to see a movie wothout him. 
"""

I think the author is in the wrong but curious what you think.
Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

The partner consistently refuses to participate in these outings, using various excuses. Now, the author goes on their own, and the partner is upset, asking to cancel to go another day. The author refuses, saying they can go whenever the partner wants.

The user thinks the author is in the wrong, but I need to consider both sides. The author's actions could be seen as reasonable because they're trying to engage with their child when the partner isn't available. However, maybe the partner feels overlooked or that the author is making decisions without consulting them. On the other hand, the author did mention the plan and faced a negative reaction. The partner's behavior of constantly refusing might indicate a lack of willingness to participate, which could be an issue.

I should consider if taking the child out on their own is a legitimate choice, especially since the partner has shown disinterest. The cost is minimal (£7 each), so money isn't a real issue. The author is fulfilling their role as a parent by providing activities for the child. The partner's reaction might stem from feeling excluded or not being involved. However, the author isn't going without the partner's consent; they're making a choice when the partner isn't available.

In terms of fairness, the author isn't doing anything wrong by taking the child out on their own, especially since the partner has consistently refused. The partner might need to address their own issues with not wanting to participate. The author's response to the partner's complaint is valid because they've already been denied previously. So, the author isn't in the wrong here. The answer should be B (No).
